Edited August 8, 2013 by mcirish3

I don't know why I'm so happy that you did this, but I am.

I'm assuming you took the LCM of the bodies' orbital periods?

Yes though I just figured out all my data above is wrong busily reworking. I was off (as far as I can tell, still working out questionable details) by a factor of 10^55 very bad. New best calculation is a period of 1.6*10^21 years. will fully update once the kinks are worked out.

I think your number for Kerbin is the altitude above the sun's surface, not the SMA. The data I use says Kerbin's SMA is 13,599,840,256 meters.

And what value of mu are you using for the sun? Your orbital periods look a little off. Best number I have is 1.17233279483249e18 m^3/s^2. Likewise for the planets with moons, periods look a tiny bit off.

I'm getting these numbers from https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0AuySrGPsDeq2dFdaS19xc2lobGc2aWNXUkJsZlVtWFE#gid=0

Edited August 8, 2013 by tavert

I think your number for Kerbin is the altitude above the sun's surface, not the SMA. The data I use says Kerbin's SMA is 13,599,840,256 meters.

And what value of mu are you using for the sun? Your orbital periods look a little off. Best number I have is 1.17233279483249e18 m^3/s^2. Likewise for the planets with moons, periods look a tiny bit off.

I'm getting these numbers from https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0AuySrGPsDeq2dFdaS19xc2lobGc2aWNXUkJsZlVtWFE#gid=0

Where is that sheet from? I used the mass of Kerbol listed on the wiki and the value of big G listed on google. I did not use the (80) since it is uncertain.

And yes, my Kerbin value was wrong.

Edited August 8, 2013 by mcirish3

The physical constant G has a pretty high uncertainty, and I don't think the mass on the wiki is given to very many digits of precision. The gravitational parameter mu is more useful. Check the source links below the spreadsheet, there's a link to an old forum thread where someone pulled the data to full precision directly from the game.
